questions.question: The SI unit of electric current is the _____.
questions.explanation: The SI Unit of electric current is the ampere.
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.question: The SI unit of electric charge is _____.
questions.explanation: The SI unit of charge (Q) is Coulomb (C).
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.question: The SI unit of potential difference is _____.
questions.explanation: The S.I unit of potential difference is Volt (V).

questions.question: Electric current is the flow of _____.
questions.explanation: The flow of charges from a region of excess electrons to the region deficit in electrons constitutes electric current.
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.question: Protons are _____ charged.
questions.explanation: Protons are positively charged
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.question: Electrons are _____ charged.
questions.explanation: Electrons are negatively charged
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.question: Neutrons do not have any charge, they are _____.
questions.explanation: Neutrons do not have any charge, that is, they are neutral.
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.question: The centre of an atom is called the _____.
questions.explanation: The centre of the atom is called the nucleus.
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.question: Electrons revolve around the nucleus in paths called _____.
questions.explanation: Electrons revolve around the nucleus in paths called orbits.
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.question: The mathematical relation between current (I) and charge (Q) is I = _____.
questions.explanation: Mathematical relation between electric current (I) and electric charge (Q) is represented as: I = Q/t.
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.question: 1 Volt = 1 Joule / 1 _____.
questions.explanation: 1 Volt = 1 Joule/ 1 Coulomb.

questions.question: The direction of _____ current is opposite to the direction of flow of electrons.
questions.explanation: The direction of the conventional current is taken to be opposite to the direction of flow of electrons.

questions.question: A combination of two or more cells is called a _____.
questions.explanation: A number of primary cells connected in series forms a battery.

questions.question: The dry cell was developed in 1887 by _____ of Japan.
questions.explanation: It was developed in 1887 by Yai Sakizo of Japan.

questions.question: The positive electrode is called the _____.
questions.explanation: The positive electrode is called the anode

questions.question: The negative electrode is called the _____.
questions.explanation: The negative electrode is called the cathode.

questions.question: In a dry cell, the _____ container acts as the negative electrode.
questions.explanation: A dry cell essentially consists of a zinc container, acting as the negative electrode.

questions.question: In a dry cell, the _____ rod acts as the positive electrode.
questions.explanation: A carbon rod with a brass cap is placed at the centre. This acts as a positive electrode

questions.question: The electrolyte in a dry cell is a moist paste of ammonium chloride and _____.
questions.explanation: The electrolyte is a moist paste of ammonium chloride (NH4Cl) and plaster of Paris.

questions.question: A primary cell _____ be recharged.
questions.explanation: It cannot be recharged after use.

questions.question: Secondary cells are also called storage cells or _____.
questions.explanation: Secondary cells are also called storage cells or accumulators.

questions.question: An electric _____ converts mechanical energy into electrical energy.
questions.explanation: An electric generator or dynamo is a device that converts mechanical energy into electrical energy.

questions.question: In hydroelectric power stations, turbines are rotated by flowing _____.
questions.explanation: In hydroelectric power stations, turbines are rotated by flowing water.

questions.question: A thermal power plant uses energy from _____ fuels.
questions.explanation: A thermal power plant uses energy produced from fossil fuels

questions.question: A nuclear power plant uses _____ energy to generate electric current.
questions.explanation: An atomic or nuclear power plant uses nuclear energy to generate electric current.

questions.question: A _____ cell converts solar energy into electrical energy.
questions.explanation: The device used to convert solar energy into electrical energy is called the solar cell.

questions.question: A large number of solar cells connected together form a solar _____.
questions.explanation: A solar panel is formed by a large number of solar cells connected together.

questions.question: The blades of a _____ are rotated by wind to generate electricity.
questions.explanation: The energy of the wind is used to rotate the blades of a windmill, which in turn, generates electricity.

questions.question: An electric circuit is a _____ path in which electric current flows.
questions.explanation: An electric circuit is defined as a closed path in which electric current flows.

questions.question: A circuit is said to be _____ when the switch is on and current flows through it.
questions.explanation: A circuit is said to be closed or complete when electric current flows through it. This condition is obtained when the switch is on.

questions.question: A circuit is said to be _____ when no electric current flows through it.
questions.explanation: A circuit is said to be open when no electric current flows through it.

questions.question: In household wiring, all appliances are connected in _____.
questions.explanation: In household wiring system, all the appliances are connected in parallel

questions.question: The component that opposes the flow of current is called a _____.
questions.explanation: A resistor which opposes the flow of current in the circuit.

questions.question: The measure of opposition to current flow in a circuit is called _____.
questions.explanation: The measure of the opposition to current flow in an electrical circuit is known as resistance.

questions.question: Substances that allow electric current to flow through them are called _____.
questions.explanation: Substances which allow electric current to flow through them easily are called conductors.

questions.question: Substances that do not allow electric current to flow through them are called _____.
questions.explanation: Substances which do not allow electric current to flow through them are called insulators or non-conductors.

questions.question: _____ is used in making good quality electric wires.
questions.explanation: Copper is used in making good quality electric wires

questions.question: _____ water is an insulator while impure water is a conductor.
questions.explanation: Pure water are insulators' and 'Impure water is also a conductor.

questions.question: Air is an _____, so if any part of the circuit is broken, no current flows.
questions.explanation: Air is an insulator. Therefore, if any part of the circuit is broken, there is no flow of electric current.

questions.question: Electric wires are always covered with _____ to make them safe.
questions.explanation: Electric wires are always covered with insulators, such as plastic, to make them safe.

questions.question: The unit Volt is named after the Italian Physicist _____.
questions.explanation: It is named after the Italian Physicist Alessandro Volta.

questions.question: An electrochemical cell converts _____ energy into electrical energy.
questions.explanation: It converts chemical energy into electrical energy.

questions.question: The nucleus of an atom consists of protons and _____.
questions.explanation: It consists of protons and neutrons.
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.question: The amount of charge flowing per unit _____ is known as electric current.
questions.explanation: The amount of charge flowing per unit time is known as electric current.
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.question: Electric charge is of two types, namely positive and _____.
questions.explanation: Electric charge is of two types, namely positive and negative

questions.question: A high potential region is produced by the _____ of electrons.
questions.explanation: A high potential region is produced by the accumulation of electrons due to larger force of repulsion.

questions.question: By convention, the direction of electric current is from _____ terminal to negative terminal.
questions.explanation: The direction of flow of electric current is taken to be from the positive terminal of the battery... to the negative terminal.

questions.question: The carbon rod in a dry cell has a _____ cap on top.
questions.explanation: A carbon rod with a brass cap is placed at the centre.

questions.question: The carbon rod in a dry cell is surrounded by a mixture of manganese dioxide and _____.
questions.explanation: This acts as a positive electrode and is surrounded by a mixture of manganese dioxide (MnO2) and carbon (C) in a muslin bag.

questions.question: The outer body of the zinc container in a dry cell is insulated with thick cardboard or _____.
questions.explanation: The outer body (except the metal base) of the zinc container is insulated with thick cardboard or plastic.

questions.question: Primary cells connected in _____ form a battery.
questions.explanation: A number of primary cells connected in series forms a battery.

questions.question: In a battery, the positive terminal of one cell is in contact with the _____ terminal of the next cell.
questions.explanation: They are connected in such a way that the positive terminal of the preceding cell is in contact with the negative terminal of the following cell.

questions.question: Lead accumulator is an example of a _____ cell.
questions.explanation: Examples of secondary cells are lead accumulator, Edison accumulator and nickel-iron accumulator.

questions.question: Electricity from the mains reaches our homes through transformers and _____ wires.
questions.explanation: It is then transferred to houses through various transformers and overhead wires on poles or through underground cables.

questions.question: In a generator, a copper wire is rotated in a _____ field to produce electric current.
questions.explanation: In a generator, an electric conductor such as copper wire is rotated in a magnetic field to produce an electric current.

questions.question: Small generators used at homes for backup during power cuts use fuels such as diesel or _____.
questions.explanation: Small generators such as those used at homes for back-up during power cuts use fuels such as diesel or kerosene to run the turbine.

questions.question: Solar cells are used to power electronic calculators, watches, streetlights and _____.
questions.explanation: Solar cells are used to power electronic calculators, watches, streetlights and lighthouses.

questions.question: Solar panels are used in artificial satellites and _____ stations.
questions.explanation: Solar panels are used in artificial satellites and space stations.

questions.question: The more the speed of the wind, the more will be the _____ generated.
questions.explanation: The more the speed of the wind, the more will be its energy and thus more electricity is generated.

questions.question: An electric switch helps in making and _____ of the circuit.
questions.explanation: An electric switch to turn on or off the electric device' and 'Helps in making and breaking of the circuit'.
questions.source_section: Components of an Electric Circuit and Their Functions

questions.question: A plug key helps in keeping a circuit open or closed for _____ duration.
questions.explanation: A plug key which helps in keeping a circuit open or closed for longer duration.
questions.source_section: Components of an Electric Circuit and Their Functions

questions.question: The arrow marked in a circuit diagram shows the direction of _____ current.
questions.explanation: The arrow marked in a circuit diagram shows the direction of conventional current.

questions.question: In a series circuit, there is a _____ of voltage among appliances.
questions.explanation: Series circuit: There is a sharing of voltage (potential difference).

questions.question: In a parallel circuit, each appliance gets the _____ voltage.
questions.explanation: Parallel circuit: Each appliance gets the original voltage.

questions.question: In a series circuit, all appliances work _____.
questions.explanation: Series circuit: All appliances work simultaneously.

questions.question: In a parallel circuit, all appliances work _____.
questions.explanation: Parallel circuit: All appliances work independently.

questions.question: Household appliances are connected in parallel with separate _____ so they can be operated independently.
questions.explanation: In household wiring system, all the appliances are connected in parallel with separate switches. Thus, they can be operated independently.

questions.question: _____ are devices having resistance to the passage of an electric current.
questions.explanation: Resistors are devices or electrical components having resistance to the passage of an electric current.

questions.question: All _____ such as copper, silver, nickel, aluminium, iron and steel are conductors.
questions.explanation: All metals such as copper, silver, nickel, aluminium, iron and steel are conductors.

questions.question: Cotton, rubber, paper, glass, ceramics, plastic, wood and _____ water are insulators.
questions.explanation: Cotton, rubber, paper, glass, ceramics, plastic, wood and pure water are insulators.

questions.question: The human body allows current to pass through it, but it is not as good a conductor as _____.
questions.explanation: The human body also allows current to pass through it, but it is not as good a conductor as metals.

questions.question: In fact, 90% of outside power lines are _____ wires and uninsulated.
questions.explanation: In fact, 90% of outside power lines are bare wires and uninsulated.

questions.question: Power lines may have _____ coating, but it provides no insulation or protection from electric shock.
questions.explanation: They may have weather coating, but it provides no insulation or protection from electric shock.

questions.question: While doing electrical work, stand on an insulator such as a rubber mat or a _____ board.
questions.explanation: Stand on an insulator such as a rubber mat or a wooden board when doing electrical work.

questions.question: Put off the main switch immediately in case of _____ circuit and fire.
questions.explanation: Put off the main switch immediately in case of short circuit and fire.

questions.question: Use only _____ marked wires for electrical connections.
questions.explanation: Use only ISI marked wires.

questions.question: Cover all naked wires with _____ tape.
questions.explanation: Cover all naked wires with insulating tape.

questions.question: A _____ is a safety device that melts and breaks the electric circuit when current exceeds permissible value.
questions.explanation: A fuse is a safety device containing a wire that melts and breaks the electric circuit when the current exceeds permissible value.
questions.source_section: Prepping for PISA - Fuse vs MCB

questions.question: MCB stands for Miniature Circuit _____.
questions.explanation: Miniature Circuit Breakers (MCBs) are commonly used in homes and commercial settings.
questions.source_section: Prepping for PISA - Fuse vs MCB

questions.question: Georges Leclanche invented the Leclanche cell in _____.
questions.explanation: In 1866, he invented the Leclanche cell
